text: we're looking at what's ahead for
markets several key economic indicators
come out this week I'm Winnie o'kelly
reporting for business day live i'll be
speaking to reporters essica silver
greenberg she's been covering the
fallout from a security breach that has
affected one and a half million credit
card holders brian Stelter from the
media desk will also be joining me he's
here to talk about a booking battle
between the major Network morning shows
but first i'm joined by leo Krakowski
he's the chief investment officer at BNY
Mellon wealth management good morning
leo good morning buddy so we're coming
off of a really great first quarter for
the stock market after sort of you know
more difficult results last year
everyone wonders can this continue
what's your perspective I think it can
continue although probably not at the
pace of the first quarter the underlying
fundamentals are still very supportive
for the US equity market the economy's
growing corporate earnings we expect SP
earnings to be between 100 and hundred
and five dollars this year which means a
p/e ratio of about 14 times so the
market is still pretty reasonably valued
despite this run-up it's been very well
supported by earnings now all that said
we're entering into a seasonally
challenging period for the market
there's going to be more focused on the
year-end elections and the massive
fiscal cliff that our Fed Chairman calls
the expiration of tax cuts and austerity
kicking in so I think we might look back
on this as the strongest quarter of the
year but we do think the market closes
that you're higher than where we're
trading today that's a little different
than how economist look at the year
because I've actually been expecting it
to gain traction as we go forward what
do you expect for example short term
when the jobs report comes out on Friday
it's going to be a choppy week because
it's unusual to have such an important
report come out on a day when the equity
markets closed and the bond market only
has a half a day of trading so I think
this week is going to be a tough one to
gauge the the beginning of the second
quarter now that said I think the year
when we when we tally it all up is
probably one where GDP growth is two to
three percent to answer your question
and again one that supportive of higher
corporate earnings although not probable
get the same rate of growth that we saw
in 2011 vs2010 there's been a little bit
of a debate about whether the jobs
numbers have gotten ahead of GDP if you
if you will sort of you know how strong
is the underlying sentiment in the
economy you know what's your take on
that yeah I've kind of run out of
adjectives to describe the economy muted
anemic subpar I think with all of the
stimulus we've put behind our economy
two to three percent gdp growth is still
not where we need to be and I think
encouraging news on the employment side
but as our fed chairman said last Monday
right it's still not normal right the
folks who are out of work are out of
work a lot longer hours worked or not
where we want or need them to be so I
think we need to take and also we have
the broader civilian unemployment rate
still hovering at around fifteen percent
when we take into account those folks
who've given up looking for work or
those who have taken on part-time jobs
although they'd like to work full time
so I think we still have some wood to
chop but clearly an eight point three
percent unemployment rate which is what
we're still expecting to see on friday
is better than a ten percent
unemployment rate and and how about
translate into the stock markets are the
particular sectors we should be looking
at well i think investors need to
maintain what we call a bar bill I think
you know after a quarter like this you
don't want to give up on all of your
defensive stocks but you want to be
positioned for ongoing growth in terms
of some of the cyclical sectors so in
that in that vein we like energy and
technology I think energy underperformed
in the first quarter of the year but we
like the energy sector especially
thematically if investors are willing to
look beyond the next quarter or two I
think energy is a theme that's going to
be with us for some years to come but
you can't say technology underperformed
in the first quarter it's been carrying
a detected extremely well but cash on
the balance sheet is a huge theme I
think it's why we're going to see a nice
future for dividends and tech is really
leading the charge there so some great
cash flow numbers I think we're going to
see more merger and acquisition activity
share buybacks and obviously as
companies are still cautious about
hiring people they aren't as cautious
about hiring or investing in capital
equipment and software to continue
efficiency and productivity gains so I I
do think the capital spending cycle
continues to
work in technologies favor you know the
fund flows if I recall them correctly
show that investors have individual
investors have been a little bit on the
sideline it's been the institutions have
been plowing ahead what will it take to
get individuals to commit again oh it's
a great it's a great question and you're
so right there's still two point six
trillion dollars sitting in money market
funds earning effectively zero in the
first quarter we saw net withdrawals
from equity funds in addition into bond
funds makes us very nervous I think many
investors maybe overstaying their
welcome and things like
intermediate-term government bond funds
which feel well but my hope is that when
investors look at their statements this
quarter and they see that many bond
funds produced somewhere around zero
give or take return I think that's a
little bit of a wake-up call to at least
consider rebalancing portfolios back
towards a more normal equity target so i
think it's it's a process i I've said
you know cynicism skepticism is still
really high and that's not going to
unwind itself over the next couple of
months or even quarters so I think
that's an ongoing ongoing process so
interesting thank you very much for
joining us today Leo thank you for
having me last night Visa and MasterCard
describes a security breach at a company
called Global Payments that company is
responsible for handling online
transactions I'm joined from our
newsroom by Jessica silver Greenberg has
been following the story hello Jessica
hi Winnie so this is a really opaque
business consumers have a very hard time
understanding it they have a MasterCard
or Visa brand on their card there are
banks that issue their cards and yet
they're these other companies that are
handling their transactions can you
explain this to us that's right there
consumer still really I'm not sure they
realize that there's this third party
that is responsible really from the time
that they swipe their card at a store
the time that that payment gets sent to
the bank these companies global payments
is one of them they process millions of
transactions a day
on behalf of Visa and MasterCard and
they are largely in the shadows so when
you go to you pay at your taxi even in
New York where you swipe your card it's
not your bank it's not visa it's one of
these companies that's handling it and
now we've seen this big breach right one
and a half million card holders have had
their information how does this compare
to other breaches in the past well it's
small relative to other breaches which
have been much larger a breach at
another major payment processor called
Heartland Payment Systems in that breach
which was reported in 2009 roughly 130
million credit card accounts were
compromised so this compared to that is
relatively small but again we are
talking about 1.5 million credit card
accounts that may have been compromised
so visa said it's not going to use
Global payment anymore does that really
have any effect no what we're hearing
from both global payments and industry
consultants is that it really it has
virtually no effect on global payments
ability to process transactions of for
visa card holders and to actually the
company's allowed to sign up new
merchants to also process visa
transactions so a lot of the hoop law
and attention that's come from visas
latest move to disqualify global
payments as or to remove them from their
list of approved third-party processors
a lot of that is it's a lot of noise but
it doesn't have real implications on the
day-to-day business so help me
understand you know Congress looked at
this a few years ago and talked to the
industry who's really regulating what
happens here with these companies well
and that that's an interesting question
because that's what this breach has
really highlighted I think our is the
gap in regulation of third-party
processing the any oversight of the
processors falls largely to the States
at the moment but those laws really
govern what happens after
breach not the security that has to go
into place before breach occurs or to
prevent a breach so the laws govern
things like when you have to contact
consumers if their information has been
compromised so this is a regulatory gray
area in fact there's really no federal
oversight of this at the moment so we'll
be looking to see what happens there
thank you so much Jessica thank you and
finally a battle is brewing between the
morning television shows this week these
shows are sources of ad revenue for the
television networks that's significant
brian Stelter joins us from our media
desk to talk about why the competition
is increasing among the shows thanks for
joining me Brian thanks so we're seeing
these incredible headlines Katie
Couric's coming back Oprah's going to be
on what's going on here you know for 16
years at a show on NBC is the number one

close um there's no other streak like
that in television no other show no
their time of day and then claim to be
number one like that for so long but ABC
and good morning america is is right on
its tail the closest it's been in years
they're basically right now they're one
suburb away from being the Today Show
and so that's why this way they brought
on Katie Couric all week the former
Today Show anchor to try to beat today
and so there's some irony in that right
she's here at a totally different spot
right now what's what are the other
competitors going to do right over base
it's a full week of this so Katie
Couric's on for a full week that means
that ABC has five days to get NBC
viewers just come over once and try it
that's that's the genius perhaps of what
ABC is doing is it's not just doing a
one-day stunt they're bringing on katie
card five days in a row to get you to
try to change the channel and try their
show in fact headline on the daily news
this morning was this Katie Couric sarah
palin kind of an arguably sex discover
but it shows them punching because
tomorrow morning Sarah Palin's going to
be a co-host on Today Show now of course
four years ago Katie Couric had that
famous interview with sarah palin that
some people say really damage there are
Palin's brand so it's really a rematch
that's how it's being portrayed so help
me understand what's at stake how much
money is really involved in this morning
there's really a premium associated be
number one there's a psychological
benefit of being on top but there's also
a financial premium you get in terms of
your ad revenue these morning shows
really you know bolster the whole news
divisions for NBC ABC and CBS they help
pay the bills keep the lights on
for all the other news shows because
after all they're on for two three
sometimes four hours a day so they've
got a lot of add time out of air time to
fill that's why they're so pivotal it's
going to be interesting to watch this
week stay tuned right exactly that's all

Kelly reporting for business day live
